channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. Screening on Foreign Projects Roils Aid Groups
item.description: Nonprofit groups say the vetting is overly intrusive, undermines their mission, and may endanger the lives of their employees.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: RON NIXON
item.media:description: A United States Agency for International Development official in Nepal. The agency is collecting data on people working on government-funded projects to ensure no money goes to terrorists.

item.title: As Latin Tour Nears End, Pope Travels to Paraguay
item.description: Pope Francis highlighted Paraguay’s history to emphasize its resilience, but also criticized corruption, a delicate issue in one of Latin America’s poorest countries.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: Discussions Shift to Endgames as Nuclear Negotiations Drag On
item.description: As negotiations continued 11 days after a deadline for a deal, actions by the Iranians, the Americans and the Europeans seemed to indicate a deal could be underway.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Chad: Bomber Kills at Least 14 People
item.description: A man wearing a burqa detonated a bomb outside the main market in the capital, Ndjamena, on Saturday, killing 14 people, a police spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: Memorial Ceremony Disrupted
item.description: A crowd of furious Bosnian Muslims attacked Serbia’s prime minister with stones and water bottles on Saturday, marring the 20th anniversary commemorations of the massacre in Srebrenica, in eastern Bosnia.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Aleksandar Vucic of Serbia, center, surrounded by bodyguards.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Burundi: Presidential Election Delayed
item.description: Burundi’s presidential election has been postponed by nearly a week, a presidential spokesman said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Meeting on Greece Debt Breaks Up With No Deal
item.description: Eurozone finance ministers planned to reconvene Sunday after ending the meeting late Saturday, leaving the Continent hours from what could be a historic rupture.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: French Finance Minister Michel Sapin, center, arrived for a meeting of eurozone finance ministers in Brussels on Saturday.

item.title: U.N. Cease-Fire Fails to Take Hold in Yemen
item.description: A military coalition led by Saudi Arabia carried out airstrikes and their foes, the Houthi rebels, battled rival militias in several cities.
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: China Fences In Its Nomads, and an Ancient Life Withers
item.description: The Chinese government is in the final stages of a 15-year-old effort to transform millions of pastoralists who once roamed China’s vast borderlands.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nomad in Xinjiang Province. China wants nomads settled to preserve grasslands.

item.title: Spanish Look to Havana to Repay an Old Debt
item.description: Many émigrés are hoping that a new era of openness between the United States and Havana could help remove obstacles to recovering what they lost. But obstacles remain.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Gianfranco Tripodo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carmen Gómez Álvarez-Varcácel, 90, showed photos of her sons, taken when the family lived in Cuba. With Havana seeking reconciliation with the West, she hopes she might recover jewelry and other items seized as she left revolutionary Cuba.

item.title: Chinese Officials to Restructure Beijing to Ease Strains on City Center
item.description: Beijing will undertake a major restructuring of the capital government as part of a broader plan to create a giant urban corridor in northern China, officials said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Unlikely Targets in Cross Hairs as Russia Aims to Expose Foreign Influence
item.description: Among the groups that Russia has placed on a list of “foreign agents” are an organization that supports the mothers of soldiers and the country’s oldest human rights organization.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Sergei Guriev, an economist, left Russia, fearing persecution for his liberal political views.

item.title: Chinese Authorities Detain and Denounce Rights Lawyers
item.description: At least five lawyers from a firm that specialized in rights cases have been detained and accused of running a criminal syndicate to smear the Communist Party.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: In Tourist Destinations, a Picture of Excess
item.description: A surge in reckless and damaging behavior by tourists, which often goes viral on social media, has officials considering measures to limit the damage.
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: People along a neon-lit stretch of Magaluf. The mayor says tourist behavior has led to a backlash among residents. He is seeking additional security personnel and a ban on free drinks.

item.title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Blast at Italian Consulate in Cairo
item.description: The attack, which killed one person, was the first major bombing of a diplomatic mission in Egypt since the start of an insurgency nearly two years ago.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Security officials inspected the site of an explosion outside the Italian Consulate on Saturday. It was the first bombing of a foreign diplomatic mission since an insurgency began two years ago.

item.title: U.S. Strike Is Said to Kill Senior ISIS Militant in Afghanistan
item.description: The death of the senior militant, Hafiz Saeed Khan, in an airstrike Friday was reported by Afghan officials but could not be confirmed independently.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: A ‘Lost Boy’ Battles AK-47s With Education
item.description: Valentino Deng is using royalties from “What Is the What,” the book about him by Dave Eggers, to transform young lives.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF
item.media:description: Valentino Deng was 7 when he fled Marial Bai, in what is now South Sudan, and eventually ended up in America. He later returned home and built a successful school with royalties from a best-selling book about him by Dave Eggers.

item.title: South Sudan Enemies Find Uneasy Refuge Together at a U.N. Base
item.description: People from three ethnic groups engaged in a civil war have made homes on a United Nations peacekeeping base.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA
item.media:description: People from at least three warring ethnic groups live side by side in a camp near Malakal, South Sudan.

item.title: With Greeks Now Ready to Make a Deal, What Can We Expect?
item.description: Meetings this weekend in Brussels will determine if Europe will press ahead with negotiations for a third bailout, or leave Greece to exit the euro.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Greek Debt Crisis Pits Greeks Against Germans
item.description: What happens when rules-bound Germany meets anything-goes Greece? A standoff, in this case.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: At a bank in Athens, graffiti made clear the resentment some Greeks have against the Germans’ hard-line economic positions.
